block.p: WorldCom and Sprint End Their Agreement to Merge WorldCom and Sprint officially abandoned their $115 billion merger, bowing to pressure from regulators, who were concerned that the creation of such a large telecommunications company would stifle competition.

Far from dampening the outlook for ever-larger communications concerns, the dissolution of the agreement fueled speculation about consolidation among large telecommunications companies, with both WorldCom and Sprint being mentioned as potential takeover targets for foreign companies. Shares in WorldCom rose $3.4375, to $47.9375, while shares of Sprint increased 68.75 cents, to $48. [Page C5.]

Two Insurers Face Bias Lawsuits MetLife and Prudential Insurance have been accused in two class-action lawsuits of charging their black customers higher premiums for life insurance than white customers. The companies said that they stopped using race as a factor about 50 years ago but that some of these remained in effect. They said they stopped collecting premiums on the policies in the early 1980's. [C2.]

Nasdaq Outpaces Dow and S.& P. Strong quarterly reports touched off new buying in technology stocks, lifting the Nasdaq composite index 75.27 points, or 1.8 percent, to 4,174.86. The rest of the market mostly languished as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.92 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,495.84, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 5.30 points, or 0.05 percent, to 10,788.71. [C6.]

Senate Rejects Hold on Gas Tax The Senate voted against suspending the federal gasoline tax through the November election, calling the measure a calibrated attempt to cozy up to voters at the expense of the nation's roads and highways. [A1.]

Tyco Says S.E.C. Inquiry Is Over The Securities and Exchange Commission has ended its investigation of Tyco International's accounting practices without taking action against the company, Tyco said. The news helped lift shares of Tyco $3, to $51.50. [C7.]

G.E. Earnings Increase by 20% General Electric, benefiting from a robust economy and its aggressive push into selling products online, said that its second-quarter earnings rose 20 percent, beating Wall Street projections by a penny. [C2.]

Advertising Bursts Into Song Television commercials that feature elaborate musical production numbers, long out of favor on Madison Avenue, are making a comeback. Big advertisers, like the Gap, are offering viewers minimusicals with maxi-casts for products as disparate as books, shampoo, apparel, soft drinks, cleaners and credit cards. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]

Price of Imported Goods Up 0.8% The price of goods imported to the United States rose 0.8 percent last month, the fastest pace since February, driven by a jump in oil costs, government figures showed. [C17.]

Ford to Take a $3.3 Billion Charge Ford will take $3.3 billion in charges for costs of spinning off its Visteon parts unit and reorganizing its European business, resulting in its first quarterly loss since the end of 1992. [C17.]
